column4: Hello--I'm installing ubuntu v7.04. What should I use for a Mount Point as a beginner?
You'll need a mount point of '/' without the quotes.
Does it give you an example of choices?
Please list some -- my memory isn't that great; I can't remember the liveCD install by heart ;)
Oh. you want to have the larger part of it ext3, and a smaller part (usually no more than double your physical memory) as 'swap'
So, if you have a 20gb area you're converting, and have 512mb RAM, make about 19gb ext3, mounted as '/', and about 1gb swap.
Yes. swap is like a windows pagefile -- essentially, it's just an area that your computer uses for extended memory.
Are you keeping windows on your machine, or are you doing an install to an empty HD?
Ahh. Easiest way to do it, then, is to make a primary partition with the linux space, and then do logicals for the smaller ones (or so I've found).
Really, it doesn't matter how you do it, so long as you've got a big ext3 as / in the end and a small swap.
Logical partitions, sorry.
If you're like me (which you won't be) you'll have 384mb of memory, so mine was about 750mb.
For linux, you need at least 4gb to install the filesystem on.
But better to have more for space for files and whatnot.
Exactly. Set the mount point of the 25gb as '/' formatted as ext3, and set the 1024mb as 'swap'.
Wine is absolutely brilliant. I would most highly recommend it.
Yes. gparted works great for it.
You can do it inside of linux and the liveCD.
however, the default installer has a partitioner by default.
I'd swear by it. It's the one I recommended to you :P
It matters little. I do it at the end, but it doesn't matter.
Yeah, sure.
